**Mount Shasta** ([Karuk](/wiki/Karuk_language "Karuk language"): _Úytaahkoo_
or "White Mountain")[5][6] is a [potentially
active](/wiki/Volcano#Popular_classification_of_volcanoes "Volcano")[7]
volcano at the southern end of the [Cascade Range](/wiki/Cascade_Range
"Cascade Range") in [Siskiyou County,
California](/wiki/Siskiyou_County,_California "Siskiyou County, California").
At an elevation of 14,179 feet (4321.8 m), it is the second-highest peak in
the Cascades and the [fifth-highest in the
state](/wiki/List_of_California_fourteeners "List of California fourteeners").
Mount Shasta has an estimated volume of 85 cubic miles (350 km3), which makes
it the most voluminous [stratovolcano](/wiki/Stratovolcano "Stratovolcano") in
the [Cascade Volcanic Arc](/wiki/Cascade_Volcanoes "Cascade Volcanoes").[8][9]

The mountain and surrounding area are part of the [Shasta–Trinity National
Forest](/wiki/Shasta%E2%80%93Trinity_National_Forest "Shasta–Trinity National
Forest").

## Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mount_Shasta&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

Mount Shasta is connected to its satellite cone of [Shastina](/wiki/Shastina
"Shastina"), and together they dominate the landscape. Shasta rises abruptly
to tower nearly 10,000 feet (3,000 m) above its surroundings.[4] On a clear
winter day, the mountain can be seen from the floor of the [Central
Valley](/wiki/Central_Valley_\(California\) "Central Valley \(California\)")
140 miles (230 km) to the south.[10][_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
mountain has attracted the attention of poets,[11] authors,[12] and
presidents.[13]

The mountain consists of four overlapping volcanic cones that have built a
complex shape, including the main summit and the prominent [satellite
cone](/wiki/Satellite_cone "Satellite cone") of 12,330 ft (3,760 m) Shastina,
which has a visibly conical form. If Shastina were a separate mountain, it
would rank as the fourth-highest peak of the Cascade Range (after [Mount
Rainier](/wiki/Mount_Rainier "Mount Rainier"), Rainier's [Liberty
Cap](/wiki/Liberty_Cap_\(Washington\) "Liberty Cap \(Washington\)"), and Mount
Shasta itself).[4]

Mount Shasta's surface is relatively free of deep glacial
[erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion") except, paradoxically, for its south side
where Sargents Ridge[14] runs parallel to the [U-shaped](/wiki/U-shaped_valley
"U-shaped valley") Avalanche Gulch. This is the largest glacial valley on the
volcano, although it does not now have a glacier in it. There are seven named
[glaciers](/wiki/Glacier "Glacier") on Mount Shasta, with the four largest
([Whitney](/wiki/Whitney_Glacier "Whitney Glacier"),
[Bolam](/wiki/Bolam_Glacier "Bolam Glacier"), [Hotlum](/wiki/Hotlum_Glacier
"Hotlum Glacier"), and [Wintun](/wiki/Wintun_Glacier "Wintun Glacier"))
radiating down from high on the main summit cone to below 10,000 ft (3,000 m)
primarily on the north and east sides.[4] The Whitney Glacier is the longest,
and the Hotlum is the most voluminous glacier in the state of California.
Three of the smaller named glaciers occupy [cirques](/wiki/Cirque_\(landform\)
"Cirque \(landform\)") near and above 11,000 ft (3,400 m) on the south and
southeast sides, including the [Watkins](/wiki/Watkins_Glacier "Watkins
Glacier"), [Konwakiton](/wiki/Konwakiton_Glacier "Konwakiton Glacier"), and
[Mud Creek](/wiki/Mud_Creek_Glacier "Mud Creek Glacier") glaciers.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mount_Shasta&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: History")]

The oldest-known [human settlement](/wiki/Human_settlement "Human settlement")
in the area dates to about 7,000 years ago.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

At the time of Euro-American contact in the 1820s, the Native American tribes
who lived within view of Mount Shasta included the
[Shasta](/wiki/Shasta_\(tribe\) "Shasta \(tribe\)"),
[Okwanuchu](/wiki/Okwanuchu "Okwanuchu"), [Modoc](/wiki/Modoc_people "Modoc
people"), [Achomawi](/wiki/Achomawi "Achomawi"), [Atsugewi](/wiki/Atsugewi
"Atsugewi"), [Karuk](/wiki/Karuk "Karuk"), [Klamath](/wiki/Klamath_people
"Klamath people"), [Wintu](/wiki/Wintu "Wintu"), and [Yana](/wiki/Yana_people
"Yana people") tribes.

The historic eruption of Mount Shasta in 1786 may have been observed by
[Lapérouse](/wiki/Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Galaup,_comte_de_Lap%C3%A9rouse "Jean-
François de Galaup, comte de Lapérouse"), but this is disputed. Although
perhaps first seen by Spanish explorers, the first reliably reported land
sighting of Mount Shasta by a European or American was by [Peter Skene
Ogden](/wiki/Peter_Skene_Ogden "Peter Skene Ogden") (a leader of a [Hudson's
Bay Company](/wiki/Hudson%27s_Bay_Company "Hudson's Bay Company") trapping
brigade) in 1826. In 1827, the name "Sasty" or "Sastise" was given to nearby
[Mount McLoughlin](/wiki/Mount_McLoughlin "Mount McLoughlin") by Ogden.[15]
The name was transferred to present-day Mount Shasta in 1841, partly as a
result of work by the [United States Exploring
Expedition](/wiki/United_States_Exploring_Expedition "United States Exploring
Expedition").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Mount_Shasta_Farm.jpg/220px-
Mount_Shasta_Farm.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mount_Shasta_Farm.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mount_Shasta_Farm.jpg "Enlarge")

Mount Shasta as seen from a small farm south of Weed, California

Beginning in the 1820s, Mount Shasta was a prominent landmark along what
became known as the [Siskiyou Trail](/wiki/Siskiyou_Trail "Siskiyou Trail"),
which runs at Mount Shasta's base. The Siskiyou Trail was on the track of an
ancient trade and travel route of Native American footpaths between
California's [Central Valley](/wiki/Central_Valley_\(California\) "Central
Valley \(California\)") and the [Pacific Northwest](/wiki/Pacific_Northwest
"Pacific Northwest").

The [California Gold Rush](/wiki/California_Gold_Rush "California Gold Rush")
brought the first Euro-American settlements into the area in the early 1850s,
including at [Yreka, California](/wiki/Yreka,_California "Yreka, California")
and [Upper Soda Springs](/wiki/Upper_Soda_Springs "Upper Soda Springs"). The
first recorded ascent of Mount Shasta occurred in 1854 (by Elias Pearce),
after several earlier failed attempts. In 1856, the first women (Harriette
Eddy, Mary Campbell McCloud, and their party) reached the summit.[16][17]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/King_WhitneyGlacier.jpg/220px-
King_WhitneyGlacier.jpg)](/wiki/File:King_WhitneyGlacier.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:King_WhitneyGlacier.jpg "Enlarge")

[Clarence King](/wiki/Clarence_King "Clarence King") exploring the [Whitney
Glacier](/wiki/Whitney_Glacier "Whitney Glacier") in 1870. This was the first
[glacier](/wiki/Glacier "Glacier") in the continental United States discovered
and named. It was named for [Josiah Whitney](/wiki/Josiah_Whitney "Josiah
Whitney"), head of the California Geological Survey.

By the 1860s and 1870s, Mount Shasta was the subject of scientific and
literary interest. A book by California pioneer and entrepreneur [James
Hutchings](/wiki/James_Mason_Hutchings "James Mason Hutchings"), titled
_Scenes of Wonder and Curiosity in California_ , contained an account of an
early summit trip in 1855.[18] The summit was achieved (or nearly achieved) by
[John Muir](/wiki/John_Muir "John Muir"), [Josiah
Whitney](/wiki/Josiah_Whitney "Josiah Whitney"), [Clarence
King](/wiki/Clarence_King "Clarence King"), and [John Wesley
Powell](/wiki/John_Wesley_Powell "John Wesley Powell"). In 1877, Muir wrote a
dramatic popular article about his surviving an overnight blizzard on Mount
Shasta by lying in the hot sulfur springs near the summit.[19] This experience
was inspiration to [Kim Stanley Robinson](/wiki/Kim_Stanley_Robinson "Kim
Stanley Robinson")'s short story "Muir on Shasta".

The 1887 completion of the [Central Pacific
Railroad](/wiki/Central_Pacific_Railroad "Central Pacific Railroad"), built
along the line of the Siskiyou Trail between California and Oregon, brought a
substantial increase in tourism, lumbering, and population into the area
around Mount Shasta. Early resorts and hotels, such as [Shasta
Springs](/wiki/Shasta_Springs "Shasta Springs") and [Upper Soda
Springs](/wiki/Upper_Soda_Springs "Upper Soda Springs"), grew up along the
Siskiyou Trail around Mount Shasta, catering to these early adventuresome
tourists and mountaineers.

In the early 20th century, the [Pacific Highway](/wiki/Pacific_Highway_\(US\)
"Pacific Highway \(US\)") followed the track of the Siskiyou Trail to the base
of Mount Shasta, leading to still more access to the mountain. Today's version
of the Siskiyou Trail, [Interstate 5](/wiki/Interstate_5 "Interstate 5"),
brings thousands of people each year to Mount Shasta.

From February 13–19, 1959, the [Mount Shasta Ski
Bowl](/wiki/Mount_Shasta_Ski_Park "Mount Shasta Ski Park") obtained the record
for the most snowfall during one storm in the U.S., with a total of 15.75 feet
(480 cm).[20]

Mount Shasta was declared a [National Natural
Landmark](/wiki/National_Natural_Landmark "National Natural Landmark") in
December 1976.[21]

### Religion and
legends[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mount_Shasta&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Religion and legends")]

Main article: [Legends of Mount Shasta](/wiki/Legends_of_Mount_Shasta "Legends
of Mount Shasta")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Sunrise_on_Mount_Shasta.jpg/220px-
Sunrise_on_Mount_Shasta.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sunrise_on_Mount_Shasta.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sunrise_on_Mount_Shasta.jpg "Enlarge")

Sunrise on Mount Shasta

The lore of some of the [Klamath Tribes](/wiki/Klamath_Tribes "Klamath
Tribes") in the area held that Mount Shasta is inhabited by the Spirit of the
Above-World, Skell, who descended from heaven to the mountain's summit at the
request of a Klamath chief. Skell fought with Spirit of the Below-World, Llao,
who resided at [Mount Mazama](/wiki/Mount_Mazama "Mount Mazama") by throwing
hot rocks and lava, probably representing the volcanic eruptions at both
mountains.[22]

Italian settlers arrived in the early 1900s to work in the mills as
stonemasons and established a strong Catholic presence in the area. Many other
faiths have been attracted to Mount Shasta over the years—more than any other
Cascade volcano.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] [Mount Shasta
City](/wiki/Mount_Shasta,_California "Mount Shasta, California") and
[Dunsmuir, California](/wiki/Dunsmuir,_California "Dunsmuir, California"),
small towns near Shasta's western base, are focal points for many of these,
which range from a [Buddhist](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") monastery ([Shasta
Abbey](/wiki/Shasta_Abbey "Shasta Abbey"), founded by [Houn Jiyu-
Kennett](/wiki/Houn_Jiyu-Kennett "Houn Jiyu-Kennett") in 1971) to modern-day
Native American rituals. A group of Native Americans from the [McCloud
River](/wiki/McCloud_River "McCloud River") area practice rituals on the
mountain.[23]

Mount Shasta has also been a focus for non-Native American legends, centered
on a hidden city of advanced beings from the lost continent of
[Lemuria](/wiki/Lemuria_\(continent\) "Lemuria \(continent\)").[24] The legend
grew from an offhand mention of Lemuria in the 1880s, to a description of a
hidden Lemurian village in 1925. In 1931, Wisar Spenle Cerve wrote _Lemuria:
the lost continent of the Pacific_ , published by the
[Rosicrucians](/wiki/Rosicrucian "Rosicrucian"), about the hidden Lemurians of
Mount Shasta that cemented the legend in many readers' minds.[24]

In August 1987, believers in the spiritual significance of the [Harmonic
Convergence](/wiki/Harmonic_Convergence "Harmonic Convergence") described
Mount Shasta as one of a small number of global "power centers".[25] Mount
Shasta remains a focus of "[New Age](/wiki/New_Age "New Age")" attention.[26]

## Geology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mount_Shasta&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Geology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Mount_Shasta_satellite_view_Jan_2014.jpg/220px-
Mount_Shasta_satellite_view_Jan_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mount_Shasta_satellite_view_Jan_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mount_Shasta_satellite_view_Jan_2014.jpg "Enlarge")

Satellite ([Landsat 8](/wiki/Landsat_8 "Landsat 8")) view of Mount Shasta

About 593,000 years ago, [andesitic](/wiki/Andesite "Andesite") lavas erupted
in what is now Mount Shasta's western flank near McBride Spring. Over time, an
ancestral Mount Shasta [stratovolcano](/wiki/Stratovolcano "Stratovolcano")
was built to a large but unknown height; sometime between 300,000 and 360,000
years ago the entire north side of the [volcano](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano")
collapsed, creating an enormous [landslide](/wiki/Landslide "Landslide") or
[debris avalanche](/wiki/Debris_avalanche "Debris avalanche"), 6.5 cu mi (27
km3)[27] in volume. The slide flowed northwestward into [Shasta
Valley](/wiki/Shasta_Valley "Shasta Valley"), where the [Shasta
River](/wiki/Shasta_River "Shasta River") now cuts through the 28-mile-long
(45 km) flow.

What remains of the oldest of Mount Shasta's four cones is exposed at Sargents
Ridge on the south side of the mountain. Lavas from the Sargents Ridge vent
cover the Everitt Hill shield at Mount Shasta's southern foot. The last lavas
to erupt from the vent were [hornblende](/wiki/Hornblende
"Hornblende")-[pyroxene](/wiki/Pyroxene "Pyroxene") andesites with a
hornblende [dacite](/wiki/Dacite "Dacite") dome at its summit. Glacial erosion
has since modified its shape.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The next cone to form is exposed south of Mount Shasta's current summit and is
called Misery Hill. It was formed 15,000 to 20,000 years ago from pyroxene
andesite flows and has since been intruded by a hornblende dacite
dome.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Black_Butte_from_Weed%2C_California-750px.jpg/220px-
Black_Butte_from_Weed%2C_California-750px.jpg)](/wiki/File:Black_Butte_from_Weed,_California-750px.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Black_Butte_from_Weed,_California-750px.jpg "Enlarge")

Nearby [Black Butte](/wiki/Black_Butte_\(California\) "Black Butte
\(California\)") from [Weed, California](/wiki/Weed,_California "Weed,
California")

There are many buried glacial scars on the mountain which were created in
recent glacial periods ("ice ages") of the present [Wisconsinian
glaciation](/wiki/Wisconsin_glaciation "Wisconsin glaciation"). Most have
since been filled in with [andesite](/wiki/Andesite "Andesite")
[lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava"), [pyroclastic flows](/wiki/Pyroclastic_flow
"Pyroclastic flow"), and [talus](/wiki/Scree "Scree") from lava domes.
Shastina, by comparison, has a fully intact summit crater indicating Shastina
developed after the [last ice age](/wiki/Last_glacial_period "Last glacial
period"). Shastina has been built by mostly pyroxene andesite lava flows. Some
9,500 years ago, these flows reached about 6.8 mi (10.9 km) south and 3 mi
(4.8 km) north of the area now occupied by nearby [Black
Butte](/wiki/Black_Butte_\(California\) "Black Butte \(California\)"). The
last eruptions formed Shastina's present summit about a hundred years later.
But before that, Shastina, along with the then forming Black Butte dacite
[plug dome](/wiki/Plug_dome "Plug dome") complex to the west, created numerous
[pyroclastic flows](/wiki/Pyroclastic_flow "Pyroclastic flow") that covered 43
sq mi (110 km2), including large parts of what is now [Mount Shasta,
California](/wiki/Mount_Shasta,_California "Mount Shasta, California") and
[Weed, California](/wiki/Weed,_California "Weed, California"). Diller Canyon
(400 ft (120 m) deep and 0.25 mi (400 m) wide) is an avalanche chute that was
probably carved into Shastina's western face by these flows.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The last to form, and the highest cone, the Hotlum Cone, formed about 8,000
years ago. It is named after the Hotlum glacier on its northern face; its
longest lava flow, the 500-foot-thick (150-metre) Military Pass flow, extends
5.5 mi (8.9 km) down its northeast face. Since the creation of the Hotlum
Cone, a dacite dome intruded the cone and now forms the summit. The rock at
the 600-foot-wide (180-metre) summit crater has been extensively
hydrothermally altered by sulfurous [hot springs](/wiki/Hot_spring "Hot
spring") and [fumaroles](/wiki/Fumarole "Fumarole") there (only a few examples
still remain).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In the last 8,000 years, the Hotlum Cone has erupted at least eight or nine
times. About 200 years ago the last significant Mount Shasta eruption came
from this cone and created a pyroclastic flow, a hot [lahar](/wiki/Lahar
"Lahar") (mudflow), and three cold lahars, which streamed 7.5 mi (12.1 km)
down Mount Shasta's east flank via Ash Creek. A separate hot lahar went 12 mi
(19 km) down Mud Creek. This eruption was thought to have been observed by the
explorer [La Pérouse](/wiki/Jean-
Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Galaup,_comte_de_La_P%C3%A9rouse "Jean-François de Galaup,
comte de La Pérouse"), from his ship off the California coast, in 1786, but
this has been disputed. [28]

### Volcanic
status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mount_Shasta&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Volcanic status")]

During the last 10,000 years, Mount Shasta has erupted an average of every 800
years, but in the past 4,500 years the volcano has erupted an average of every
600 years. The last significant eruption on Mount Shasta may have occurred
about two centuries ago.[3]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Diller_Canyon.jpg/283px-
Diller_Canyon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Diller_Canyon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Diller_Canyon.jpg "Enlarge")

Diller Canyon on Shastina from Weed

Mount Shasta can release [volcanic ash](/wiki/Volcanic_ash "Volcanic ash"),
[pyroclastic flows](/wiki/Pyroclastic_flow "Pyroclastic flow") or
[dacite](/wiki/Dacite "Dacite") and [andesite](/wiki/Andesite "Andesite")
[lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava"). Its deposits can be detected under nearby small
towns. Mount Shasta has an explosive, eruptive history. There are
[fumaroles](/wiki/Fumarole "Fumarole") on the mountain, which show Mount
Shasta is still alive.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The worst-case scenario for an eruption is a large pyroclastic flow, such as
what occurred in the [1980 eruption of Mount St.
Helens](/wiki/1980_eruption_of_Mount_St._Helens "1980 eruption of Mount St.
Helens"). Since there is ice, such as [Whitney Glacier](/wiki/Whitney_Glacier
"Whitney Glacier") and [Mud Creek Glacier](/wiki/Mud_Creek_Glacier "Mud Creek
Glacier"), [lahars](/wiki/Lahar "Lahar") would also result. Ash would probably
blow inland, perhaps as far as eastern [Nevada](/wiki/Nevada "Nevada"). There
is a small chance an eruption could result in a collapse of the mountain, as
happened when [Mount Mazama](/wiki/Mount_Mazama "Mount Mazama") in
[Oregon](/wiki/Oregon "Oregon") collapsed to form what is now called [Crater
Lake](/wiki/Crater_Lake "Crater Lake"), but this is of much lower
probability.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The [United States Geological Survey](/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey
"United States Geological Survey") monitors Mount Shasta[29] and rates it as a
very high-threat volcano.[30]

## Climbing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mount_Shasta&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Climbing")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Shasta_boulab.jpg/170px-
Shasta_boulab.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shasta_boulab.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shasta_boulab.jpg "Enlarge")

Mount Shasta's west face, June 2009

Many climbers attempt the summit of Mount Shasta. The summer climbing season
runs from late April until October, although many attempts are made in the
winter.[4] In winter, Sargents Ridge and Casaval Ridge, to the east and west
of Avalanche Gulch,[31] respectively, become the most traveled routes, to
avoid avalanche danger. Mount Shasta is also a popular destination for
[backcountry skiing](/wiki/Backcountry_skiing "Backcountry skiing"). Many of
the climbing routes can be descended by experienced skiers, and there are
numerous lower-angled areas around the base of the mountain.[4]

The most popular route on Mount Shasta is Avalanche Gulch route, which begins
at the Bunny Flat Trailhead and gains about 7,300 feet (2,200 m) of elevation
in approximately 11.5 miles (18.5 km) round trip. The crux of this route is
considered to be to climb from Lake Helen, at approximately 10,443 feet (3,183
m), to the top of Red Banks. The Red Banks are the most technical portion of
the climb, as they are usually full of snow/ice, are very steep, and top out
at around 13,000 feet (4,000 m) before the route heads to Misery Hill.[32] The
Casaval Ridge route is a steeper, more technical route on the mountain's
southwest ridge best climbed when there's a lot of snow pack. This route tops
out to the left (north) of the Red Banks, directly west of Misery Hill. So the
final sections involve a trudge up Misery Hill to the summit plateau, similar
to the Avalanche Gulch route.[33]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Mount_Shasta_west_face.jpg/220px-
Mount_Shasta_west_face.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mount_Shasta_west_face.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mount_Shasta_west_face.jpg "Enlarge")

Mount Shasta's west face as seen from Hidden Valley high on the mountain. The
west face gulley is an alternate climbing route to the summit.

No quota system currently exists for climbing Mount Shasta, and reservations
are not required. However, climbers must obtain a summit pass and a wilderness
permit to climb the mountain. Permits and passes are available at the ranger
station in Mount Shasta and the ranger station in McCloud, or climbers can
obtain self-issue permits and passes at any of the trailheads 24 hours a
day.[34]
